original_caption: This flowchart illustrates the pathophysiological cascade of SARS-CoV-2 infection leading to multi-organ dysfunction and death. The process begins with SARS-CoV-2 entering epithelial cells, triggering reactive oxygen species (ROS) that induce cell death and activate intracellular pathways including NLRP3 and NF-κB. These signals initiate immune invasion, prompting macrophages to trigger activated T cells, macrophages, and neutrophils, which release cytokines—specifically elevated IL-1, IL-2, IL-6, TNF-α, and IFN-γ—culminating in a cytokine storm. This storm drives an inflammatory cascade that may lead to bacterial infection, acute respiratory distress syndrome, sepsis, and ultimately multi-organ dysfunction syndrome, ending in death. Concurrently, tissue damage releases PAMPs and DAMPs that activate pattern recognition receptors (PRR), further amplifying cytokine production. On the right side, the diagram maps organ-specific clinical manifestations: lungs exhibit dry/productive cough, rhinorrhoea, sneezing, sore throat, dyspnoea, haemoptysis, and fever; gastrointestinal tract shows nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, and lower GI infection; brain symptoms include headache, impaired consciousness, confusion, stroke, muscle injury, anosmia, hypogeusia, and brain inflammation; cardiovascular system presents with palpitations, chest tightness, blood clots, heart attacks, and cardiac inflammation; liver shows raised AST; kidneys manifest oliguria, haematuria, proteinuria, and rapid blood pressure drop; microcirculation leads to hypoxemia; and eyes develop conjunctivitis. Arrows indicate unidirectional progression or activation, while bidirectional arrows between tissue damage and PRR activation suggest feedback loops. Components are grouped into stages: viral entry, immune response, systemic inflammation, and organ failure, with color-coded cell types (green for T cells, purple for macrophages, pink for neutrophils) and labeled anatomical illustrations.

original_caption: This flowchart illustrates the cascading impacts of drought and flooding on small and medium enterprises (SMEs) across three cities—Gaborone, Lusaka, and Nairobi—as indicated by a legend using red, orange, and purple circular markers respectively. At the top, “Drought” and “Flooding” feed into “Water and electricity supply disruption,” which branches into four primary consequences: “Supply chain disruption and/or supplier price increases,” “Down time / service delivery compromised,” “Changes in demand,” and “Asset loss/inventory damage.” Each of these connects to secondary effects such as “Reduced productivity at times of disruption,” “Unable to fulfil orders or other obligations to customers,” “Change to price of sale,” and “Machines take time to restart.” These further lead to operational and financial outcomes including “Scaling back of business operations,” “Reductions in workforce,” “Difficulty honouring financial commitments e.g. loan payments,” and “Reduced investment in business development.” All pathways converge toward three final outcomes: “Profits impacted,” “Business lost to competitors,” and “Business viability at risk,” each marked with all three city indicators. A parallel branch labeled “Investment into adaptation measures” lists examples like acquiring new equipment, diversification, and relocation, and connects bidirectionally to several intermediate nodes, suggesting feedback loops between adaptation and impact mitigation. Arrows indicate unidirectional causal flows from top to bottom, with some lateral connections showing interdependencies among intermediate stages.

original_caption: This flowchart outlines a two-stage genetic association study, divided into Discovery and Replication phases. The Discovery phase begins with 31,969 individuals from 19 African American cohorts and 2 African cohorts, progressing through genotype pre-imputation quality control, imputation using the 1000 Genome Phase I reference, association analysis for SBP/DBP/PP/HTN traits, pre-meta-analysis QC, fixed-effects meta-analysis, multi-trait association analysis, and conditional independent analysis. From this, 72 independent SNPs with P < 1×10⁻⁶ are selected for replication. Three downstream analyses branch off: Pathway Analysis, Functional Annotation, and Cell Type Group Analysis, each represented by an oval node connected via gray arrows. The Replication phase incorporates four distinct cohorts—4,187 from African cohorts, 14,016 from East Asian cohorts, 23,914 from European cohorts, and 12,278 from a Hispanic cohort—which feed into a trans-ethnic meta-analysis. This yields 11 independent variants on 9 loci reaching P < 1.25 × 10⁻⁸ in the combined discovery and replication meta-analysis. Two final outputs emerge: eQTL Analysis and Hypertensive Mice Model, the latter highlighted with a gray outline around its oval node. All process steps are enclosed in rectangular boxes, while analytical outcomes are in ovals; directional flow is indicated by black downward arrows for sequential steps and gray diagonal arrows for branching analyses.

original_caption: This flowchart illustrates the progression of participants through a clinical study, beginning with 1,034 children who tested RDT-positive for P. falciparum malaria; from these, 314 were excluded for failing to meet inclusion criteria, including absence of asexual parasitemia (111), parasitemia below 2,000 (95) or above 200,000 (79), hemoglobin under 5 g/dL (14), Z-score below 3SD (7), presence of danger signs (4), or other reasons (4), leaving 720 enrolled children. These 720 were randomized into two treatment arms: 360 received artemether-lumefantrine (AL) and 360 received dihydroartemisinin-piperaquine (DP), each subdivided equally by site—Niangoloko, Nanoro, and Gourcy—with 120 per site per arm. In the AL arm, 27 participants were lost to follow-up or withdrew due to protocol violation (7) or other reasons (20), resulting in 333 reaching the day-28 outcome (109 from Niangoloko, 114 from Nanoro, 110 from Gourcy). In the DP arm, 21 participants were lost or withdrew (10 for protocol violation, 11 for other reasons), yielding 339 reaching the day-28 outcome (113 from each site); of these, 337 subsequently reached the day-42 outcome (112 from Niangoloko, 112 from Nanoro, 113 from Gourcy), with 2 additional participants lost to follow-up between day 28 and day 42. All boxes are connected by solid arrows indicating unidirectional flow, with exclusion and loss-to-follow-up branches extending horizontally from the main vertical pathway.
